body:
``` rust
use std::ops::Deref;

struct Foo<T> {
    xs: [T; 0]
}

impl<T> Deref for Foo<T> {
    type Target = [T];
    fn deref(&self) -> <Self as Deref>::WhyDoesThisCompile {
        123
    }
}

fn main() {
}
```

This (and the example in the original report) compiles today with `rustc 1.0.0-nightly (3ef8ff1f8 2015-02-12 00:38:24 +0000)`. In fact, the body of the `deref` function can be whatever type you fancy, and same goes for the type of `Target`, it doesn't matter. If you try to use the deref on a value, though, you get this lovely ICE:


If you make `Foo` non-generic, then the same ICE happens even without actually deref-ing a `Foo` value, which suggests the generic type has to be instantiated before any problems arise.

Discussed with @nikomatsakis today.  We agreed that there are (at least) two distinct bugs being illustrated here, as is somewhat implied in the description.

I have a fix for the `<Type as Trait>::NoExist` issue.  I will file a separate bug just for that, and then put up the pull request sometime afterward.

---

Oddly enough, our stdlib seems to be taking slight advantage of this bug: [`fn cloned` in `core::iter`](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/f0f7ca27de6b4e03f30012656dad270cda55a363/src/libcore/iter.rs#L981) refers to the projected type  `<Self::Item as Deref>::Output`, but the [`Deref` trait's associated item](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/f0f7ca27de6b4e03f30012656dad270cda55a363/src/libcore/ops.rs#L1051) is named `Target`.

Which raises the question: How was/is this currently working?  In the playpen, I was not able to demonstrate any actual hole in the library via this mistake; i.e. calling `.cloned()` on an iterator over non-cloneables is still rejected.  But why/how does it make the connection to reject the code here?  (Or is this a sign that my own checking code is too strict, and what the core library is currently doing is somehow legal Rust?  Or is there some other associated type named `Output`, but for a different trait, attached to `Self` in the case I was testing?)
This is fixed, and has tests.
